Mitochondrial inheritance refers to the passage of mitochondria (which have their own DNA) from mother to child, affecting traits coded by those mitochondrial genomes. In contrast, X-linked inheritance involves genes located on the X chromosome, which follow a specific pattern of inheritance influenced by sex (males having XY chromosomes and females XX).
